Antiwar Council Plans Attack on Draft Boards
Moratorium activities in the coming months will center
on draft resistance and reaching Nixon's "silent
majority."
Speaking Thursday night in Shriver Hall, Larry Kudlow,
Regional Coordinator for the Moratorium Committee of the
Middle Atlantic States, noted the belief of many people that
the Moratorium Committee is giving up, because of the
great popularity of Nixon's Vietnamization policy. He stated that the Committee has not given up and will continue its
work, as long as the President refuses to give a firm commitment for pulling out of Vietnam.
Kudlow described the Committee as having been
"relatively invisible" for the last few months. However,
he said that it has been working quietly to set up seven
regional offices across the country. In addition the Committee has been making plans for March and April activities.

ings, planned for the following week.
For April 15 massive, nationwide tax demonstrations
are being planned. A great effort will be made to involve
middle and lower class adults in the antiwar cause. Kudlow
said that the Moratorium Committee plans a low-keyed
effort to draw critical relationships between military
policy and economic problems, such as Nixon's HEW veto
and his requests for ABM appropriations. Moratorium
workers will attempt to prove how the Vietnam War is
responsible for tax hikes, inflation, the threat of recession,
and the decrease in the buying power of money.
Kudlow
declared the Moratorium Committee to be
opposed to "Nixon's illusion of the silent majority, not to
the American people...I don't believe that people are
really supporting the President.If you scratch one,quarter
inch below the surface, you'll see great frustration and rising discontent," he said. The Committee will try to show
the people that "it is Nixon and Laird who are polarizing
the country, not us."

Civil Disobedience

Americans Are Nonpolitical

By HOWARD LEVENSON

In March action will center around draft boards, with
rallies and vigils. Civil disobedience will be emphasized.
It will take the form of a massive "We Won't Go" statement, hopefully to be released at a press conference in
Washington.
The Committee is seeking a direct confrontation with the
Selective Service System.It hopes to organize ten thousand
draftees to refuse induction. Kudlow said that the government would not prosecute ten thousand draft resisters.
He said that the government is already letting draft resisters go free, citing as an example the refusal to prosecute
David Hawk of the Moratorium Committee.
Kudlow said that ultimately he and his co-workers seek
repeal of the draft and its replacement with a volunteer
army. He emphasized that the Moratorium Committee has
not decided on this course of action because of opposition
to all wars and warfare, but because of opposition to the
Vietnam War.
The statements on the draft and the volunteer army are
to be released the week of March 16, so as to coordinate
with the anti-draft week being organized by the New
Mobilization Committee for the week of March 16-23.

fact that people either feel very uncomfortable discussing

The Council's Incompetence

THE WIZARD OF ID

•

It has been a common theme of past years' NewsLetters to harp on the fact that past years' Student
Councils have been mis-oriented, slow-moving and ineffective. It has been equally common for members of the
Student Council to accuse the News-Letter of a great deal
of empty criticism and distortion of the news. This year's
situation is, however, different. Neither has the Student
Council been in the public eye, nor has it done very much
to rise to its own defense.
In fact, the conduct of the Council in the past few
months has been so scandalously negligent as to raise
questions anew about its necessity and usefulness. Not
only has the S.C. consistently refrained from attacking the
multifold problems of the community, but it has been slow
even to deal with questions and conflicts unearthed by the
other groups on campus. What is even more disheartening
is the fact that recent meetings have either been cancelled
or 'tampered with' due to lack of attendance.
Figures from the Council's roll book indicate that one
member has five unexcused absences, three members have
three nch, and eight others have one apiece. Counting
excused absences--a process which essentially involves a
pre-meeting announcement of the fact—the number is substantially higher.
None of these shortcomings and weaknesses, however,
can compare with the S.C.'s actions of the past few days.
In a series of virtually unparalleled moves, it went past admitting its ineffectiveness at dealing with foreign issues to
an :admission of helplessness at coping with its own constitution.
By refusing to discipline its wayward members, the
Council has virtually given up any pretensions of power,
prestige or influence. It is an implicit admission to students, faculty and administration alike that nothing the
council officially does need be taken seriously, since it
cannot even take the question of its own attendance seriously.
It is clear to all that there are a number of weak and
confusing aspects to the Council's constitution. The membership question is one of these, in that no clear procedural
matters have been delineated by which a member is officially expelled. For the S.C. to deal with this legislatively
would be a laudable, if not necessary, step. The fact, however, that procedure was entirely and blithely ignored lends
considerable doubt to the Council's ability to deal properly
and legalistically with any serious issue twhich, confronts
that body.

An answer to the inevitable what to do this weekend
question. For one of the next two weekends, anyway.
Not a movie, as every film in tewn is either rated G
or is one that you saw in New York two months ago. A
Play.
For those of you who missed the microscopic posters, Theatre Hopkins is currently presenting Alfred
Jarry's Ubu Roi in the Barn Theatre. First produced
in 1896, causing literal and literary riots, this seminal
work has been of unquestionably significant influence in
the history of modern theatre.
As a first crack in the
walls of Hugo-Zola realism and late Victorianism, Ubu
Rol spawned the Gallic madness
of Dada and Surrealism
and the absurdity of Beckett
and Ionesco which we still
admire to srespectfully today.
Perhaps this is the only value of Ubu Rol, as a piece
of historical
interest rather than literary merit. The
avant-garde of 1896 bears little surprise for today's
playwatcher -- note the relative calm with which Grotowsky's revolutionary Polish Laboratory Theatre was
received. Attending Jarry's play is almost analagous
to those
intolerable semesters of survey courses and
prerequisites (you know, the "necessary background"
bullshit.) It would be analagous if Ubu Rol were not
entertaining.

Garbled Green Candles
A puppeteer opens the play by manipulating some marionnettes while crossing and re-crossing the stage, muttering something barely discernable (very poor enunciation) about a green candle. Later on another character
Speaks of a green candle, but his lines were garbled and
unintelligible also. So much for the symbolism of green

candles.
Then the two main characters, Mere and Pere Ubu,
appear. Captain of the Dragoons and a former king of
Aragon, Pere Ubu „; is a crude slob who is persuaded by
his wife to murder the reigning king of Poland and assume
the throne. ,(Jarry wrote, "As for the action - that takes
place in Poland - that is to say - nowhere.") The Ubus'
conspiracy succeeds, assasinating- all but the moronic
prince Bougrelas. An oppressive totalitarianism is
established, imposing exorbitant taxes and executing all
the notiles, magistrates, and financiers.
Pere Ubu's lust for money and blood can be restrained
only by his dominating trait, cowardice. He becomes
helpless with fear at the thought of Bougrelas,the legitimate heir sworn to vengenace in a scene which amateurishly parodies the' ghost scene in Hamlet.

Sea-Sick Sailors
When one of Pere Ubu's fellow conspirators turns against him, war results. His gaudy ostentation waving
in the breeze, Pere Ubu gallops off to smashing defeat,
though it is not. clear whether anyone has won. Pere
Ubu, his wife, and their loyal flunkies end up sea sick
and alone on a ship, until an actor displays a sign
reading "End". (This play concludes in a manner
strikingly similar to Ingmar Bergman's recent Shame.)
Although an important milestone in the twentieth century's attack on reason and order, Ubu Rol seems quaintly mild today. Jarry's humor is concentrated in the use
of broad slapstick and grotesque shifts of action and
mood. Theatre Hopkins has augmented the script with
many humorous touches: corpses which flutter their
arms and float off stage like angles, a messenger who
leaps on stage and freezes in the one-point stance of

Mercury. The dialogue, though witty in spots, is mostly on a par with a Three Stooges short (which is not
to say that it is bad, but...)
Jarry's battle against meaning does show in the total
unreality of his exaggerated characters and events. All
the conventional "themes" which the play seems to relate -- war and greed are bad,crime does not pay, etc. -are so overwhelmed by the absurdity that they are ridiculed into non-existence.

Added Devices Distracting
Unfortunately, Jarry's original script has been expanded by some superfluous and confusing devices. The puppeteer at the opening of the play and the prominent
prescence of four large dice as part of the set immediately suggests fate, chance, life is a game, man is manipulated by Unknown Powers, etc., etc. These are ideas
which do not appear in the dialogue or action at all.
Theatre Hopkins' choice of props was wise - birdcages
for royal crowns, a dust shovel for Pere Ubu's sceptre
of power, and a curved cane (Pere Ubu calls it his "shitter") employed alternately as a sword, whip, and telescope. Much is added by the imaginative costuming:
Pere Ubu is bloated to the proportions of three Santa
Clauses, his wife appears with lewdly gargantuan .bust
and buttocks.
A word on the acting. The characters are flat unidimensional silhouettes and should be played that way.
Donald Hart does just that in the role of Pere Ubu. Mere
Ubu is done by Ruth Lawson Walsh, who adds an enjoyable amount of coarse spirit and boisterousness to her
part. ,And the role of Captain Bordure acquires comic
elements totally independent of Jarry's words, due to
Joe Bandiera's hilarious diction.

By JOHN HOLLIS
An answer to the inevitable what to do this weekend
question. For one of the next two weekends, anyway.
Not a movie, as every film in tewn is either rated G
or is one that you saw in New York two months ago. A
Play.
For those of you who missed the microscopic posters, Theatre Hopkins is currently presenting Alfred
Jarry's Ubu Roi in the Barn Theatre. First produced
in 1896, causing literal and literary riots, this seminal
work has been of unquestionably significant influence in
the history of modern theatre.
As a first crack in the
walls of Hugo-Zola realism and late Victorianism, Ubu
Rol spawned the Gallic madness
of Dada and Surrealism
and the absurdity of Beckett
and Ionesco which we still
admire to srespectfully today.
Perhaps this is the only value of Ubu Rol, as a piece
of historical
interest rather than literary merit. The
avant-garde of 1896 bears little surprise for today's
playwatcher -- note the relative calm with which Grotowsky's revolutionary Polish Laboratory Theatre was
received. Attending Jarry's play is almost analagous
to those
intolerable semesters of survey courses and
prerequisites (you know, the "necessary background"
bullshit.) It would be analagous if Ubu Rol were not
entertaining.

Garbled Green Candles
A puppeteer opens the play by manipulating some marionnettes while crossing and re-crossing the stage, muttering something barely discernable (very poor enunciation) about a green candle. Later on another character
Speaks of a green candle, but his lines were garbled and
unintelligible also. So much for the symbolism of green

candles.
Then the two main characters, Mere and Pere Ubu,
appear. Captain of the Dragoons and a former king of
Aragon, Pere Ubu „; is a crude slob who is persuaded by
his wife to murder the reigning king of Poland and assume
the throne. ,(Jarry wrote, "As for the action - that takes
place in Poland - that is to say - nowhere.") The Ubus'
conspiracy succeeds, assasinating- all but the moronic
prince Bougrelas. An oppressive totalitarianism is
established, imposing exorbitant taxes and executing all
the notiles, magistrates, and financiers.
Pere Ubu's lust for money and blood can be restrained
only by his dominating trait, cowardice. He becomes
helpless with fear at the thought of Bougrelas,the legitimate heir sworn to vengenace in a scene which amateurishly parodies the' ghost scene in Hamlet.

Sea-Sick Sailors
When one of Pere Ubu's fellow conspirators turns against him, war results. His gaudy ostentation waving
in the breeze, Pere Ubu gallops off to smashing defeat,
though it is not. clear whether anyone has won. Pere
Ubu, his wife, and their loyal flunkies end up sea sick
and alone on a ship, until an actor displays a sign
reading "End". (This play concludes in a manner
strikingly similar to Ingmar Bergman's recent Shame.)
Although an important milestone in the twentieth century's attack on reason and order, Ubu Rol seems quaintly mild today. Jarry's humor is concentrated in the use
of broad slapstick and grotesque shifts of action and
mood. Theatre Hopkins has augmented the script with
many humorous touches: corpses which flutter their
arms and float off stage like angles, a messenger who
leaps on stage and freezes in the one-point stance of

Mercury. The dialogue, though witty in spots, is mostly on a par with a Three Stooges short (which is not
to say that it is bad, but...)
Jarry's battle against meaning does show in the total
unreality of his exaggerated characters and events. All
the conventional "themes" which the play seems to relate -- war and greed are bad,crime does not pay, etc. -are so overwhelmed by the absurdity that they are ridiculed into non-existence.

Added Devices Distracting
Unfortunately, Jarry's original script has been expanded by some superfluous and confusing devices. The puppeteer at the opening of the play and the prominent
prescence of four large dice as part of the set immediately suggests fate, chance, life is a game, man is manipulated by Unknown Powers, etc., etc. These are ideas
which do not appear in the dialogue or action at all.
Theatre Hopkins' choice of props was wise - birdcages
for royal crowns, a dust shovel for Pere Ubu's sceptre
of power, and a curved cane (Pere Ubu calls it his "shitter") employed alternately as a sword, whip, and telescope. Much is added by the imaginative costuming:
Pere Ubu is bloated to the proportions of three Santa
Clauses, his wife appears with lewdly gargantuan .bust
and buttocks.
A word on the acting. The characters are flat unidimensional silhouettes and should be played that way.
Donald Hart does just that in the role of Pere Ubu. Mere
Ubu is done by Ruth Lawson Walsh, who adds an enjoyable amount of coarse spirit and boisterousness to her
part. ,And the role of Captain Bordure acquires comic
elements totally independent of Jarry's words, due to
Joe Bandiera's hilarious diction.
